content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey</origin><title>National Mineral Resource Assessment 1998</title><pubdate>2001</pubdate><serinfo><sername>Circular</sername><issue>1178</issue></serinfo><pubinfo><pubplace>Reston, Virginia</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish></pubinfo><onlink>http://mrdata.usgs.gov/nmra/</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>Estimates of the tonnages and amounts of contained metal in undiscovered deposits, mineral deposit types.</abstract><purpose>As the Nations population grows and its economy matures, greater attention is being paid to such issues as land use and environmental quality, as well as to  sustainability of mineral supplies to provide for the needs of future generations. National Mineral Resource Assessments provide a framework for addressing these issues by monitoring the continuing depletion of the Nations nonrenewable mineral wealth and by contributing information required to manage resource extraction while minimizing consequent environmental effects. For responsible stewardship of the Nations lands and resources, it is important to know in which areas future mineral resources may be located and how much metal such resources might contain (McCammon and Briskey, 1992).</purpose></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><sngdate><caldate>1996</caldate></sngdate></timeinfo><current>Publication date of the original report; subsequent reports elaborated and expanded on these results</current></timeperd><status><progress>Complete</progress><update>None image of map interface showing permissive tracts for Hot spring Au deposits, (673 x 364 pixels)</browsed><browset>PNG</browset></browse></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>These data are not observational but are interpretations made by the original authors, so accuracy must be judged by evaluating the source publications. For consistency and simplicity, some attribute values were shortened; where the original indicated that no quantitative assessment was carried out for a tract, the values in this database are simply "NA".</attraccr></attracc><logic>Assessed permissive tracts in Alaska were handled separately from those in the conterminous US even though in many cases the deposit models considered would have been the same.  However users should assume that the concept envisioned in the deposit models for Alaskan tracts might differ in particulars from the concept used in the conterminous US.</logic><complete>Hawaii was not assessed.  In addition a number of tracts indicate that no quantitative assessment was made, even though the rationale information will indicate some of the thinking that went into the decision not to produce a quantitative estimate for those tracts.</complete><posacc><horizpa><horizpar>While these tracts are defined somewhat arbitrarily, their boundaries should be understood as broad approximations of the areas intended for assessment by the authors.  In some cases it seems clear that the geometries digitized were much more precise than the assessors actually intended, so users should not assume any point close to a boundary has or does not have characteristics of the nearby polygon.</horizpar></horizpa></posacc><lineage><srcinfo><srccite><citeinfo><origin>The U.S. Geological Survey National Mineral Resource Assessment Team</origin><pubdate>2000</pubdate><title>1998 Assessment of Undiscovered Deposits of Gold, Silver, Copper, Lead, and Zinc in the United States</title><serinfo><sername>Circular</sername><issue>1178</issue></serinfo><pubinfo><pubplace>Reston, Virginia</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish></pubinfo><onlink>http://pubs.usgs.gov/circular/c1178/</onlink></citeinfo></srccite><typesrc>digital files</typesrc><srctime><timeinfo><sngdate><caldate>2000</caldate></sngdate></timeinfo><srccurr>publication date</srccurr></srctime><srccitea>cir1178</srccitea><srccontr>Permissive tracts for the conterminous US with assessment information</srccontr></srcinfo><srcinfo><srccite><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey National Mineral Resource Assessment Team</origin><origin>Schruben, Paul G. (compiler)</origin><pubdate>2002</pubdate><title>Assessment of Undiscovered Deposits of Gold, Silver, Copper, Lead, and Zinc in the United States: A Portable Document (PDF) Recompilation of USGS Open-File Report 96-96 and Circular 1178</title><serinfo><sername>Open-File Report</sername><issue>2002-198</issue></serinfo><pubinfo><publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish><pubplace>Reston, Virginia</pubplace></pubinfo><onlink>http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2002/of02-198/</onlink></citeinfo></srccite><typesrc>digital files</typesrc><srctime><timeinfo><sngdate><caldate>2002</caldate></sngdate></timeinfo><srccurr>publication date</srccurr></srctime><srccitea>ofr2002198</srccitea><srccontr>Permissive tracts for Alaska with assessment information</srccontr></srcinfo><srcinfo><srccite><citeinfo><origin>Ludington, S. B.</origin><pubdate>1996</pubdate><title>Data Base for a National Mineral-Resource Assessment of Undiscovered Deposits of Gold, Silver, Copper, Lead, and Zinc in the Conterminous United States</title><serinfo><sername>Open-File Report</sername><issue>96-96</issue></serinfo><pubinfo><publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish><pubplace>Reston, Virginia</pubplace></pubinfo><onlink>http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/of96-096/</onlink></citeinfo></srccite><typesrc>digital files</typesrc><srctime><timeinfo><sngdate><caldate>1996</caldate></sngdate></timeinfo><srccurr>publication date</srccurr></srctime><srccitea>ofr9696</srccitea><srccontr>Original report used for comparison</srccontr></srcinfo><procstep><procdesc>Permissive tracts were drawn from the previously published reports and entered into PostgreSQL relational database with PostGIS used to express the geometry.  Additional web interfaces were developed to make it easier for people outside USGS to find, get, and use these data.</procdesc><procdate>2014</procdate></procstep></lineage></dataqual><spdoinfo><direct>Vector</direct><ptvctinf><sdtsterm><sdtstype>G-polygon</sdtstype><ptvctcnt>5769</ptvctcnt></sdtsterm></ptvctinf></spdoinfo><spref><horizsys><geograph><latres>0.0001</latres><longres>0.0001</longres><geogunit>decimal deposits in each tract</enttypd></enttyp><attr><attrlabl>tract</attrlabl><attrdef>Coded identifier grouping polygons assessed for the same type of deposit in a given geographic region</attrdef><attrdomv><udom>Short texts combining a region abbreviation with a sequence number, purely to differentiate the tract from other tracts, without additional scientific significance.</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>layer</attrlabl><attrdef>Coded identifier abbreviating the deposit type</attrdef><attrdomv><udom>Short codes (4 or 5 letters and numbers) used to abbreviate the deposit types</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>dep_type</attrlabl><attrdef>Type of mineral deposit for which the number of undiscovered deposits in the tract was estimated</attrdef><attrdomv><udom>Plain texts naming the deposit model used for the assessment; approximately matching the model title used in the published source (indicated by the dep_model field)</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>dep_model</attrlabl><attrdef>Coded identifier used in Cox and Singer (1986) and related references to refer to the deposit type</attrdef><attrdomv><udom>Coded identifiers indicating the model used for the assessment; most refer to Cox and Singer (1986), some indicate two models using + as a conjunction, a few indicate other USGS publications</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>mark3_id</attrlabl><attrdef>Coded identifier for the deposit type used by the MARK3 mineral assessment software</attrdef><attrdomv><codesetd><codesetn>MARK3 model identifiers</codesetn><codesets>http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1998/0356/report.pdf</codesets></codesetd></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>age</attrlabl><attrdef>General chronostratigraphic age in which mineralization is anticipated to have occurred</attrdef><attrdomv><udom>Geologic time periods or ranges expressed as the names of chronostratigraphic units.</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>region</attrlabl><attrdef>General geographic region in which the tract is located</attrdef><attrdomv><udom>Names indicating generalized geographic regions which are described more precisely in USGS Circular 1178</udom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>state</attrlabl><attrdef>States in which the tract is primarily located (space-separated list of values)</attrdef><attrdomv><codesetd><codesetn>2-letter postal abbreviations for US states</codesetn><codesets>USPS</codesets></codesetd></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>p_90</attrlabl><attrdef>Estimated number of undiscovered deposits in the tract, with 90% confidence</attrdef><attrdomv><rdom><rdommin>0</rdommin><rdommax>80</rdommax><attrunit>deposits</attrunit></rdom></attrdomv><attrdomv><edom><edomv>na</edomv><edomvd>No quantitative assessment of the tract was made.</edomvd></edom></attrdomv></attr><attr><attrlabl>p_50</attrlabl><attrdef>Estimated number of undiscovered deposits in the tract, with 50% confidence</attrdef><attrdomv><rdom><rdommin>0</rdommin><rdommax>600</rdommax><attrunit>deposits</attrunit></rdom></attrdomv><attrdomv><edom><edomv>na</edomv><edomvd>No quantitative assessment of the deposits</attrdef><attrdomv><udom>Last names of members of the assessment team, in comma-separated lists.
